tasks.title: 4-7-8 Breathing
tasks.description: A calming technique that activates your parasympathetic nervous system.

content.instruction: Breathe in for 4 seconds, hold for 7, exhale for 8.

tasks.evidence: MBSR breathing technique, proven to reduce cortisol levels

tasks.title: Box Breathing
tasks.description: Used by Navy SEALs to stay calm under pressure.

content.instruction: Equal counts: inhale, hold, exhale, hold.

tasks.evidence: Military stress reduction technique with documented effectiveness

tasks.title: 2-Minute Calm
tasks.description: A quick reset when you're feeling overwhelmed.

content.instruction: Slow, deep breaths. No counting, just feel.

tasks.evidence: Deep breathing activates vagus nerve, reducing stress response

tasks.title: Body Scan
tasks.description: Release tension you didn't know you were holding.

content.instruction: Notice sensations from head to toe, releasing tension as you go.

tasks.evidence: MBSR body scan, reduces physical symptoms of stress

tasks.title: Physiological Sigh
tasks.description: The fastest way to calm down, backed by Stanford research.

content.instruction: Double inhale through nose, long exhale through mouth.

tasks.evidence: Stanford neuroscience research by Andrew Huberman

tasks.title: Tension Release
tasks.description: Actively release the stress stored in your body.

slider.question: Where do you feel the most tension right now?

followUp.question: Take 30 seconds to consciously relax that area. How did it go?

tasks.evidence: Progressive muscle relaxation technique from CBT

tasks.title: Exhale Focus
tasks.description: Longer exhales tell your body it's safe.

content.instruction: Inhale naturally, then exhale twice as long.

tasks.evidence: Extended exhale activates parasympathetic response

tasks.title: Breathing Check-In
tasks.description: How are you breathing right now?

content.question: Before this moment, how were you breathing?
content.instruction: Take three slow breaths right now.
content.completion: Notice the difference? Your breath is always available to reset.

tasks.evidence: Breath awareness is foundational to mindfulness practice

tasks.title: Energy Audit
tasks.description: Understand what's draining and charging you.

content.question: What drained your energy today?

tasks.evidence: Energy management from CBT and occupational psychology

tasks.title: Mood Check
tasks.description: Name it to tame it.

slider.question: How would you rate your mood right now?

followUp.question: What word best describes how you feel?

tasks.evidence: Affect labeling reduces amygdala activation (UCLA research)

tasks.title: Boundary Check
tasks.description: Are you protecting your energy?

content.question: Did you say 'yes' to something today that you wanted to say 'no' to?
options: I didn't have to make that choice today

followUp.message: It's okay. Boundaries are a practice, not perfection. What would help you next time?
options: Accepting that 'no' is a complete sentence

tasks.evidence: Boundary-setting is key to burnout prevention (Maslach research)

tasks.title: Day Review
tasks.description: A quick reflection before you close the day.

content.question: How would you describe today overall?
content.notePrompt: Anything you want to remember about today?
content.notePlaceholder: Optional: a moment, thought, or feeling...

tasks.evidence: Daily reflection improves self-awareness and emotional regulation

tasks.title: Worry Parking
tasks.description: Acknowledge worries without letting them drive.

content.question: What's taking up mental space right now?

followUp.question: Can you do anything about these right now?
options: Yes, I'll take one small action
No, I'll let them go for now
I need to think about it more
I'll write them down and come back later

content.completion: You've acknowledged them. Now give yourself permission to set them aside.

tasks.evidence: Worry postponement technique from CBT

tasks.title: Self-Compassion Moment
tasks.description: Treat yourself like you'd treat a good friend.

content.question: If a friend felt exactly how you feel right now, what would you tell them?
content.completion: Now say that to yourself. You deserve the same kindness.

tasks.evidence: Self-compassion research by Kristin Neff

tasks.title: Values Alignment
tasks.description: Are you living according to what matters most?

content.question: What matters most to you right now?

followUp.question: Did today's actions align with this?
options: I was too busy to think about it

content.completion: No judgment. Awareness is the first step to alignment.

tasks.evidence: Values clarification from Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT)

tasks.title: Progress Recognition
tasks.description: You've come further than you think.

content.question: What's one thing you've handled better recently than you would have before?
content.notePrompt: Want to capture a specific example?

tasks.evidence: Progress monitoring increases self-efficacy (Bandura)

tasks.title: Permission Slip
tasks.description: What do you need to allow yourself today?

content.question: Give yourself permission to:
content.completion: Permission granted. You don't need anyone else's approval.

tasks.evidence: Self-permission reduces internal conflict and stress

tasks.title: Tomorrow's Intention
tasks.description: Set one gentle intention for tomorrow.

content.question: Tomorrow, I will try to:
options: Focus on one thing at a time
content.completion: One intention is enough. Small shifts create big change over time.

tasks.evidence: Implementation intentions improve follow-through (Gollwitzer)

tasks.title: Inner Dialogue Check
tasks.description: What's your inner voice saying?

content.question: How has your self-talk been today?

followUp.question: Can you reframe one negative thought you had?
options: I'll try: the thought isn't 100% true
It's hard, but I can see another perspective
Not right now, but I noticed it

tasks.evidence: Cognitive restructuring from CBT

tasks.title: Needs Check-In
tasks.description: What does your body or mind need right now?

content.question: What do you need most right now?
content.completion: Can you give yourself even one of these in the next hour?

tasks.evidence: Basic needs awareness from self-care psychology

tasks.title: Three Good Things
tasks.description: The classic gratitude practice with a twist.

content.question: Pick three good things from today (big or small):

tasks.evidence: Three Good Things exercise by Martin Seligman, proven to reduce depression

tasks.title: Hidden Blessing
tasks.description: Find the silver lining in a challenge.

content.question: What's something difficult that taught you something valuable?
options: A mistake that helped me grow
A conflict that clarified what matters
A setback that revealed my strength
A loss that deepened my appreciation
I can't think of one right now
content.notePrompt: What did you learn from it?

tasks.evidence: Post-traumatic growth research and reframing techniques

tasks.title: Appreciate Your Body
tasks.description: Your body is working hard for you.

content.question: What's one thing your body did for you today that you can appreciate?
options: Kept me breathing without thinking about it
Carried me where I needed to go
Healed while I wasn't paying attention
Gave me signals about what I need
content.completion: Thank you, body. Even when you're tired, you show up.

tasks.evidence: Body gratitude improves body image and self-care behaviors

tasks.title: Simple Pleasures
tasks.description: The small things that make life good.

content.question: What simple pleasure did you enjoy recently?
content.completion: Life is made of these moments. Notice them more often.

tasks.evidence: Savoring positive experiences extends their emotional benefit

tasks.title: Person Appreciation
tasks.description: Someone in your life deserves recognition.

content.question: Think of someone who made your life better recently. What did they do?
options: Listened when I needed to talk
content.notePrompt: Want to remember who it was?
content.completion: Consider telling them. Expressed gratitude strengthens bonds.

tasks.evidence: Gratitude expression improves relationships and well-being

tasks.title: Ordinary Magic
tasks.description: What everyday miracle did you witness?

content.question: What "ordinary" thing would you miss if it were gone?
content.completion: What's ordinary is actually extraordinary. We just forget.

tasks.evidence: Perspective-taking increases gratitude and life satisfaction

tasks.title: Self-Appreciation
tasks.description: You deserve gratitude too.

content.question: What's one thing you did recently that you can be proud of?
options: Showed up when it was hard
content.completion: Acknowledging your own efforts matters. You're doing more than you think.

tasks.evidence: Self-appreciation improves self-esteem and motivation

tasks.title: Unexpected Good
tasks.description: Something good you didn't see coming.

content.question: What unexpected positive thing happened recently?
options: A kind word from a stranger
Something worked out better than expected

tasks.evidence: Noticing positive surprises counters negativity bias

tasks.title: Contrast Gratitude
tasks.description: Appreciate by comparison.

content.question: Compared to a harder time in your past, what's better now?
content.completion: Progress isn't always visible day-to-day. Zoom out sometimes.

tasks.evidence: Temporal comparison increases appreciation for current circumstances

tasks.title: Gratitude for Challenges
tasks.description: What difficulty are you handling that shows your strength?

content.question: What challenge are you facing that's also helping you grow?
options: A demanding job that's building skills
A health issue that's prioritizing self-care
I don't see the growth yet
content.completion: You're not just surviving. You're being forged.

tasks.evidence: Growth mindset and benefit-finding in adversity

tasks.title: 5-Minute Walk
tasks.description: Movement is medicine. Even a little helps.

content.instruction: Step outside or walk around your space. No destination needed.

checkIn.question: How do you feel after moving?

tasks.evidence: Even brief walks improve mood and reduce stress hormones

tasks.title: Stretch Break
tasks.description: Release the tension your body is holding.

content.instruction: Take 2 minutes to stretch however feels good.
content.question: Where did you notice the most tightness?
content.completion: Your body thanks you. Try to stretch before it screams.

tasks.evidence: Stretching reduces muscle tension and stress symptoms

tasks.title: Fresh Air Moment
tasks.description: Step outside, even just for a minute.

content.instruction: Go outside (or open a window) and take 5 deep breaths of fresh air.
content.question: What did you notice outside?
options: I just noticed the air itself
I couldn't go outside but opened a window

tasks.evidence: Nature exposure reduces cortisol and blood pressure

tasks.title: Dance Break
tasks.description: Put on one song and move however you want.

content.instruction: Play a song that makes you want to move. No rules, no audience.
content.question: How did that feel?

tasks.evidence: Dancing releases endorphins and reduces depression symptoms

tasks.title: Posture Reset
tasks.description: How you hold your body affects how you feel.

content.instruction: Right now: Roll shoulders back, lift chest, unclench jaw.
content.question: What did you notice?
options: I was more hunched than I thought
content.completion: Set a reminder to check your posture a few times a day.

tasks.evidence: Posture affects mood and energy levels (embodied cognition research)

tasks.title: Shake It Off
tasks.description: Animals shake after stress. You can too.

content.instruction: Stand up and shake your whole body for 60 seconds. Hands, arms, legs, everything.

tasks.evidence: TRE (Tension Release Exercise) helps discharge stress from the body

tasks.title: Hydration Check
tasks.description: Your brain needs water to function well.

content.question: When did you last drink water?
content.instruction: Go drink a glass of water right now.
content.completion: Dehydration causes fatigue and poor focus. Keep water nearby.

tasks.evidence: Even mild dehydration impairs cognitive performance

tasks.title: Sunshine Dose
tasks.description: Natural light regulates your energy and mood.

content.instruction: Spend 5 minutes in natural light (outside is best, window works too).
content.question: How much natural light have you had today?
content.completion: Morning light is especially powerful for energy and sleep quality.

tasks.evidence: Light exposure regulates circadian rhythm and serotonin production

tasks.title: Change of Scenery
tasks.description: A new environment can shift your mindset.

content.instruction: Move to a different room, chair, or space — even just for 10 minutes.
content.question: How long have you been in the same spot?
content.completion: Physical change creates mental change. Move your body, move your mind.

tasks.evidence: Environmental variety reduces habituation and increases alertness

tasks.title: Energy Boost
tasks.description: Quick movement to raise your energy.

content.instruction: Do 10 jumping jacks, high knees, or march in place.
content.question: How's your energy now compared to before?
content.completion: Movement creates energy. Waiting for energy to move is backwards.

tasks.evidence: Brief exercise immediately boosts alertness and mood

tasks.title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
tasks.description: Come back to the present moment.

content.instruction: Notice: 5 things you see, 4 you hear, 3 you feel, 2 you smell, 1 you taste.
content.question: Were you able to notice all five senses?
options: Yes, it brought me back to now
I tried, but my mind wandered
content.completion: This technique works anytime you feel overwhelmed or anxious.

tasks.evidence: Grounding technique from anxiety treatment protocols

tasks.title: Mindful Coffee/Tea
tasks.description: Turn a daily habit into a meditation.

content.instruction: With your next drink, pay full attention: warmth, smell, taste, sensation.
content.question: What did you notice when paying full attention?
options: My mind still wandered, but I tried
I don't have a drink right now

tasks.evidence: Everyday mindfulness is as effective as formal meditation

tasks.title: Sound Awareness
tasks.description: What sounds surround you right now?

content.instruction: Close your eyes for 30 seconds. Notice every sound.
content.question: What did you hear?

tasks.evidence: Sound meditation increases present-moment awareness

tasks.title: Single-Tasking
tasks.description: Do one thing at a time, fully.

content.question: Right now, how many things are competing for your attention?
content.instruction: For the next 10 minutes, commit to ONE task only.
content.completion: Multitasking is a myth. Single-tasking is a superpower.

tasks.evidence: Monotasking improves focus and reduces stress (multitasking research)

tasks.title: Body Awareness
tasks.description: What is your body telling you?

content.instruction: Scan your body right now. What sensations do you notice?
content.question: Check all that apply:
content.completion: Your body sends signals before your mind notices. Listen more often.

tasks.evidence: Interoceptive awareness improves emotional regulation

tasks.title: Thought Watching
tasks.description: Observe your thoughts like clouds passing.

content.instruction: For 2 minutes, just notice thoughts without engaging. Let them pass.
content.question: What was that like?
options: Challenging — thoughts kept pulling me in
Strange — I'm not used to this
I couldn't do it for long
content.completion: You are not your thoughts. You're the one watching them.

tasks.evidence: Cognitive defusion technique from Acceptance and Commitment Therapy

tasks.title: Waiting Meditation
tasks.description: Turn dead time into present time.

content.question: Next time you're waiting (in line, for something to load, etc.):
content.instruction: Instead of reaching for your phone, just be present. Notice your surroundings.
options: I don't have much waiting time
content.completion: Waiting is free meditation time. Most people miss it.

tasks.evidence: Informal mindfulness opportunities throughout the day

tasks.title: Mindful Eating
tasks.description: Taste your food like it's the first time.

content.instruction: At your next meal, eat the first few bites with full attention. No phone, no reading.
content.question: How often do you eat without distractions?
content.completion: When you eat, just eat. You'll enjoy food more and eat more appropriately.

tasks.evidence: Mindful eating improves digestion and food satisfaction

tasks.title: Appreciation Pause
tasks.description: Stop and really look at something beautiful.

content.instruction: Find something visually pleasing around you. Look at it for 30 seconds.
content.question: What did you choose to appreciate?
options: An everyday object I usually ignore

tasks.evidence: Aesthetic appreciation increases positive emotions

tasks.title: Transition Moment
tasks.description: Pause between activities.

content.instruction: Before starting your next task, take 3 breaths and consciously switch gears.
content.question: How do you usually transition between tasks?
options: I jump right to the next thing
I often feel scattered between tasks
content.completion: Transitions are opportunities to reset. Don't rush through them.

tasks.evidence: Transition rituals reduce mental fatigue and improve focus
